application_information.content:
Scenario overview

Source code repositories are a prime target by threat actors to ultimately compromise an application or system. This threat model aims to identify and mitigate the risks associated with GitHub repositories.

The threat model is tightly scoped to the Source Integrity section of Supply Chain Security as illustrated in the left side of the diagram below. The scope informs both the threat actors and the threats themselves. The threat actors may contain threats within themselves which highlights the various ways a threat actor could gain access to a GitHub repository.

Threat analysis and recommendations

Access controls restrict who can access the repository and what actions they can perform. This minimizes the attack surface and limits the potential for unauthorized changes.

Branch protection ensures that certain branches, especially critical ones like the main production branch, have strict controls in place. This helps prevent hasty or unauthorized merges.

Authentication measures, especially MFA and strong password policies, protect user accounts and make it more challenging for unauthorized actors to gain access in the first place.

Secret Scanning can help proactively identify exposed secrets in the repository, reducing the risk of unauthorized access.

Enabling automated Secret Scanning Push Protection mechanisms can prevent secrets from being committed to the repository; blocking before they are exposed.

architecture.content:
GitHub has the role of a multifaceted platform acting not only as the sole source code repository but as something that encompasses version control, project management, CI, issue and bug tracking, automation, etc.

There are a number a ways both humans and machines authenticate and interact with GitHub

  • GitHub Account
  • Okta Session
  • Personal Access Tokens and SSH keys
  • Enterprise Apps
  • 3rd Party Apps
  • Non-MFA Service Accounts

There are a number of these authentication mechanisms that reside outside of a company’s trust boundary. There is an extension of the trust boundary which is identified by having limited control mechanisms in place. For example, once an access token has been created and granted access, there is no control over the token from the customer’s organization.

There are a number of public repositories which require extra controls compared to the private repositories where anyone on the Internet can access them where it’s possible to submit a change to the code. There are a number of “types” of repositories

  • Repos that contain code that is shipped to a customer or pushed internally
  • Repos that are essential to the supply chain where they’re responsible for backporting or maintaining services
  • Repos that are not officially supported by the customer but are free for a customer or the community to download and run
  • Repos that are not products or offerings - anything else etc.

Beyond authentication there are a number of roles within a GitHub repository, there is the concept of GitHub teams which can be assigned a role, and there are outside contributors.

assumptions.content: The organization has audit and accountability policy and procedures.
The organization has access control policy and procedures in place.
The organization implements system and communications protection policy and procedures, including an access to inter-connected systems.
Physical media threats are not applicable to SaaS software accessible via public internet.
The organization has access controls for mobile devices

assumptions.comments:
GitHub provides 2FA using TOTP, SMS, passkey, security key, or GitHub mobile.
If orgs wish to manage keys, it is up to them to implement.

Implement a process for repository owners and those with admin permissions to verify the identity of external collaborators and private GitHub accounts of GC users prior to providing access.
assumptions.content: The organization implements proper authenticator management.
Threats based on rules of behavior related to social media activities are not applicable to the GitHub platform.
The organization prohibits the direct connection of any internal network or system to an external network without the use of security controls approved by the information owner.
GitHub has a secure password policy that users must adhere to.
Wireless threats are not applicable to SaaS software accessible via public internet.
The organization provides proper authorization for the operation of security systems.
The organization implements incident response policy and procedures, training, and testing.
Boundary protection threats do not apply to SaaS applications if they apply to assets not directly under the control of the client. Ex: external communication services or host-based protection.
The organization has policies for use of external information systems such as limits of use and portable storage devices.
The organization implements personnel security policy and procedures.
Hardware threats are not applicable to SaaS software accessible via public internet.

The organization employs assessors or assessment teams with full independence from the organizational unit responsible for day to day security operations to monitor the security controls in the information system on an ongoing basis.
The organization implements system and information integrity policy and procedures including information handling and retention.
Threats to transaction-based information systems are not applicable to the GitHub platform.

The organization develops, documents, and disseminates to personnel a contingency plan with defined roles and responsibilities. Contingency plans should include training and testing. Additionally, Government of Canada organizations should do their own backup of data stored in the cloud, either using an on-premises solution or a third-party service. Backups should be a part of an overall contingency and recovery plan.
The organization implements information spillage response policy and procedures, training, and testing.
The organization analyzes and correlates audit records across different repositories to gain organization-wide situational awareness.

The organization applies proper software usage restrictions such as the use of peer-to-peer file sharing technology to ensure that this capability is not used for the unauthorized distribution, display, performance, or reproduction of copyrighted work.

assumptions.comments: The org must ensure that GitHub-specific requirements are added to the Security Planning Policy and Procedures, and that they are disseminated to appropriate personnel.
assumptions.content: The organization implements security planning policy and procedures.
The organization employs assessors or assessment teams with an external independent organization to conduct security control assessments.

assumptions.comments: The org must ensure that personnel or roles with system and services acquisition responsibilities receive information, policy, and procedures for acquiring GitHub licenses
assumptions.content: The organization implements system and services acquisition policy and procedures, including the allocation of resources and the identification of functions / ports / protocols / services.

assumptions.comments: It is up to the organization to ensure that their media protection policy includes any applicable information published to GitHub
assumptions.content: The organization implements media protection policy and procedures.
Threats based on mobile code are no longer considered less secure/different to code running on other devices.

assumptions.comments:
It is the org's responsibility to ensure that TBS/CCCS ICAM policies are followed in the context of GitHub

User accounts on GitHub are, by and large, assumed to be personal accounts rather than GC network accounts. This assumption is based on the fact that GitHub users tend to use the platform as a sort of resume, accumulating a visible work history through their contributions to various repositories on the platform. As such, the account management processes required by IA-4 will have to take into consideration this reality

Implement a process for repository owners and those with admin permissions to verify the identity of external collaborators and private GitHub accounts of GC users prior to providing access.
assumptions.content: The organization implements identification and authentication policy and procedures for organizational users.
The organization implements risk assessment policy and procedures including management and assessment.

mitigations.comments: * Use pull_request_review which associates with a particular Git SHA When triggering a GitHub Workflow using a comment on a pull request

* Monitor for changes and ensure alerts are in place for any changes to visibility settings.
* Have regular auditing in place against repository settings to ensure that the visibility of the repository has not changed.
* Ensure teams are aware of the ways they can report a security incident

* Have a GitHub Security Best Practice Policy
* Ensure every GitHub repository can adhere to the policy
* Create a set of best practices around GitHub Workflows & Actions
* Have a secret management policy that is followed, creation, use, revoke, rotate, and delete

* Include checks for secrets and sensitive information during code reviews to catch inadvertent commits / exposure
* Anything found within a code review should be revoked and rotated
* Ensure code reviews are in place when creating Workflows and using Actions within the Workflows
* CODEOWNERS for the Workflow files 
* Ensure a PR is required to change Workflows

* Establish and enforce clear security policies and guidelines for secret management and access controls.
* These guidelines should include an overall secret management lifecycle, from creation to utilization to rotation and revocation.
* Treat input to the Workflow the same way as you would with an application - don’t trust user inputs

* Deploy automated scanning tools to proactively search for and detect exposed secrets
* If exposed secrets are identified, have a response plan in place where the secrets are immediately rotated
* Employ security static analysis tools to run against Workflow code and alert on security issues

* Educate contributors about the importance of not including secrets in code and how to safely store and share secrets.
* Ensure teams are aware of the robust secret management systems available to them, e.g. HashiCorp Vault, GitHub Action Secrets
* Modern attack vectors e.g. Evilginx
* Ensure employees are educated in the many forms of social engineering
* Educate developers about security best practices when creating Workflows

* Require MFA for all access to repositories.
* In the case of bots and programmatically adjusting settings the use of fine-grained access tokens should be favored. For the majority of these cases they should not have access to adjust the visibility settings so if a token was exposed it can be revoked by the customer and the scope of the functionality it can perform is reduced.
* Switch from using non-MFA service accounts to GitHub Apps which utilize authentication mechanisms within the customer’s Org trust boundary
* Set default permission for GITHUB_TOKEN

* Require a pull request before merging as to prevent arbitrary code changes where someone or a machine can push directly to a protected branch. The PR must undergo a code review by an employee (preferably 2) before being merged.
* Require approvals to prevent arbitrary commits reaching a protected branch and can prevent unintentional security vulnerability being introduced. Ideally this involved 3 people. 1 person to submit the PR and 2 people to review it.
* Dismiss stale pull request approvals when new commits are pushed to prevent a review approving a PR where the PR has been modified after the approval. The review will be dismissed and the PR will need re-approval.
* Require review from Code Owners: Sets ownership and accountability for files within the repository where a team will need to approve a PR against their files before code can be merged into a protected branch.
* Require approval of the most recent reviewable push: This protects against when a reviewer applies some suggestions to the code enabling them to approve and merge code without someone reviewing those changes.
* Prevent Allow force pushes
* Prevent Allow deletions

* Only authorized personnel should have the ability to modify visibility settings where strong access controls and permissions are set for all repositories.
* Role-based access controls should be in place following the principle of least privilege. Limit the number of individuals who can modify settings to reduce the likelihood of unauthorized or unintentional changes.
* Ensure modification of critical setting is not possible through automation (at least in most cases) where a human always needs to confirm.
* User and Group Management: Regularly review and manage user accounts and groups ensuring access is done through groups only. Also to revoke access for teams who no longer require it.
* Outside Collaborators: Should never be added to a repository
* Audit Access: audit both non-MFA service accounts and Enterprise Apps that have access to repositories ensuring the conform least privilege.

impacted_assets: business continuity and disaster recovery capabilities
threats.prerequisites: with access during a repository service disruption
threats.threat_action: exploit failover mechanisms during disaster recovery
threats.threat_impact: compromise repository availability during system restoration

threats.prerequisites: with contributor access to public repositories
threats.threat_action: inject malicious content into public documentation and wikis
threats.threat_impact: distribute misleading or harmful information to users

impacted_assets: code security controls and change management processes
threats.threat_action: manipulate automated repository configuration controls
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized changes to branch protection rules across repositories

threats.comments:
1.  Impact:
    *   Could lead to a failure of data integrity
    *   Could lead to disruption of software development
    *   Could lead to disruption, downtime for customers, and breaking SLAs for cloud production systems
        
2.  Targets
    *   Customer’s GitHub important branches within both public + private repositories
    *   Customer’s ability to develop and release code
    *   Customers’s production systems on cloud e.g. Serverless
    *   Customer’s sessions or credentials
    *   Token’s that have access to Customer’s GitHub organizations
    *   Access to another system that would lead to gaining access to GitHub e.g. Vault
        
3.  Attack Vectors
    *   Social engineering, tools to steal sessions, secret scanning tools run against source code repositories, unintentional leaks through video walkthroughs or documentation, leaked dumps of databases and other systems on the black market and generally exposed secrets
    *   A customer’s employee unintentionally submitting a change
    *   A misconfiguration issue within the repository or a security setting has not been applied
threats.threat_action: push code changes directly to protected branches
threats.threat_impact: introduction of malicious code

threats.comments:
The threat actor could gain elevated access (e.g. write or admin) or exploit a misconfiguration to comprise the repository.

1.  Impact:
    *   Could expose sensitive proprietary information, proprietary algorithms, internal tools, and/or confidential data. This could trigger severe financial, legal, and reputational consequences for the customer.
    *   Could lead to a failure of data integrity
    *   Could lead to disruption of software development
    *   Could lead to disruption, downtime for customers, and breaking SLAs for cloud production systems
        
2.  Targets
    *   Customer’s GitHub public and private repositories
    *   Customer’s ability to develop and release code
    *   Customer’s production systems on cloud e.g. Serverless
    *   Customer’s sessions or credentials
    *   Token’s that have access to customer’s GitHub organizations
    *   Access to another system that would lead to gaining access to GitHub e.g. Vault
        
3.  Attack Vectors
    *   Social engineering, tools to steal sessions, secret scanning tools run against source code repositories, unintentional leaks through video walkthroughs or documentation, leaked dumps of databases and other systems on the black market and generally exposed secrets
    *   A misconfiguration issue within the repository or a security setting has not been applied
threats.prerequisites: with access to weak or leaked credentials
threats.threat_action: take over customer repositories
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized access to customer code and secrets

threats.threat_action: share private repository contents with unauthorized external collaborators
threats.threat_impact: exposure of proprietary code to competitors

threats.threat_action: deploy malicious content through GitHub Pages
threats.threat_impact: host phishing or malware content under organization's domain

impacted_assets: repository integrations and external service connections
threats.prerequisites: with access to third-party GitHub applications
threats.threat_action: exploit vulnerable external service integrations
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized access through trusted external services

impacted_assets: repository event data and integration security
threats.threat_action: configure malicious webhook endpoints
threats.threat_impact: exfiltrate repository events and metadata

impacted_assets: internal communication and project management data
threats.threat_action: conduct social engineering through issues and discussions
threats.threat_impact: harvest sensitive information from team communications

impacted_assets: intellectual property and source code security
threats.threat_action: exfiltrate sensitive code through uncontrolled media devices
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized copying of source code

threats.comments:
The goal of the threat actor is usually to gain unauthorized access to systems, exfiltrate data, or misuse credentials for malicious purposes.

1.  Impact:
    *   Threat actors could gain unauthorized access to customer accounts, systems, or resources.
    *   Unauthorized access could lead to data breaches, further malicious activity within customer systems, financial losses, and damage to a customer’s reputation.
        
2.  Targets:
    *   Secrets like API keys, access tokens, and credentials stored within code
    *   Configuration files, hard-coded values and documentation may inadvertently contain secrets.
        
3.  Attack Vectors:
    *   Automated scanning tools and scripts to search for secrets within code and the commit history.
    *   These secrets may be exposed due to oversight from the person committing a change or an inadvertent inclusion in code.
threats.threat_action: search public repositories for exposed secrets
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized access to sensitive credentials

impacted_assets: system access credentials and cloud service security
threats.threat_action: accidentally commit sensitive credentials to public repositories
threats.threat_impact: exposure of authentication tokens and API keys

impacted_assets: audit trails and security monitoring capabilities
threats.threat_action: disable repository audit logs and security alerts
threats.threat_impact: concealment of unauthorized activities

1.  Impact:

2.  Targets
    *   Customer’s GitHub important branches within both public + private repositories
    *   Customer’s ability to develop and release code
    *   Customer’s production systems on cloud e.g. Serverless

threats.threat_action: bypass code review controls
threats.threat_impact: merging of unreviewed code changes

impacted_assets: organizational trust and access control systems
threats.prerequisites: with access to dormant usernames in the GitHub organization
threats.threat_action: create accounts mimicking previous employees
threats.threat_impact: gain trusted access using familiar identifiers

threats.comments:
This change can expose close source code, and data to a threat actor who could publicly expose it or expose it to a limited number of threat actors e.g. sell it.

1.  Impact:
    
    *   Could expose sensitive proprietary information, proprietary algorithms, internal tools, and/or confidential data. This could trigger severe financial, legal, and reputational consequences for the customer.
2.  Targets
    
    *   The customer’s GitHub organizations that contain private GitHub repositories
    *   The customer’s user’s sessions or credentials
    *   Token’s that have access to the customer’s GitHub organizations
    *   Access to another system that would lead to gaining access to GitHub e.g. Vault
        
3.  Attack Vectors
    
    *   Social engineering, tools to steal sessions, secret scanning tools run against source code repositories, unintentional leaks through video walkthroughs or documentation, leaked dumps of databases and other systems on the black market and generally exposed secrets
    *   An employee unintentionally making a repository public without understanding the consequences
threats.threat_action: gain unauthorized access to private repositories
threats.threat_impact: exposure of confidential code and secrets

impacted_assets: source code backups and version history
threats.prerequisites: with admin access to backup systems
threats.threat_action: tamper with repository backup integrity
threats.threat_impact: loss or corruption of historical code versions and configuration data

threats.prerequisites: with access to Copilot enabled repositories
threats.threat_action: leak sensitive code snippets through AI suggestions
threats.threat_impact: expose proprietary algorithms and business logic

threats.prerequisites: with access to a terminated employee's active GitHub account
threats.threat_action: access and exfiltrate proprietary source code
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized access to sensitive intellectual property

impacted_assets: source code security and repository access controls
threats.prerequisites: with compromised credentials from a GitHub user with elevated permissions
threats.threat_action: modify repository role-based access controls
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized privilege elevation across multiple repositories

threats.threat_action: inject vulnerable code patterns into organization templates
threats.threat_impact: propagate security vulnerabilities across new repositories

threats.comments:
1.  Impact:
    *   Could lead to a failure of data integrity
    *   Could lead to disruption of software development
    *   Could lead to disruption, downtime for customers, and breaking SLAs for cloud production systems
        
2.  Targets
    *   Customer’s GitHub important branches within both public + private repositories
    *   Customer’s ability to develop and release code
    *   Employees’s sessions or credentials
    *   Token’s that have access to the customer’s GitHub organizations
    *   Access to another system that would lead to gaining access to GitHub e.g. Vault
        
3.  Attack Vectors
    *   Social engineering, tools to steal sessions, secret scanning tools run against source code repositories, unintentional leaks through video walkthroughs or documentation, leaked dumps of databases and other systems on the black market and generally exposed secrets
    *   An employee unintentionally overriding the commit history of an important branch
    *   A misconfiguration issue within the repository or a security setting has not been applied
threats.prerequisites: with write permissions to protected branches
threats.threat_action: force push changes to branch history
threats.threat_impact: loss or manipulation of critical commit history

threats.threat_action: unknowingly approve the installation of malicious OAuth applications
threats.threat_impact: gain persistent access through authorized applications

threats.threat_action: perform a SQL injection attack
threats.threat_impact: the ability to modify data

impacted_assets: software supply chain and package dependencies
threats.threat_action: publish malicious packages to organization's registry
threats.threat_impact: compromise dependent projects and build processes

impacted_assets: repository security posture and vulnerability management
threats.threat_action: disable continuous security monitoring features
threats.threat_impact: prevent detection of security vulnerabilities and threats

threats.prerequisites: being compelled by their judicial system and having the required access to encryption keys and datastores
threats.threat_action: decrypt our secrets
threats.threat_impact: leads to exposure of confidential code and secrets

threats.prerequisites: with access to a personal access token or SSH key
threats.threat_action: gain unauthorized access to the GitHub authentication process
threats.threat_impact: compromise user accounts and access sensitive information stored in repositories

impacted_assets: incident response capabilities and security breach containment
threats.threat_action: suppress security incident alerts and notifications
threats.threat_impact: delay response to active repository compromises

threats.comments:
1.  Impact:
    *   Access secrets, deployment / release keys, SSH keys, PATs etc.
    *   Exfiltrate sensitive information like secrets and circumnavigate the secret redaction feature
    *   Access the GITHUB\_TOKEN
    *   Modify the contents of the repository through the GitHub API
    *   Possible cross-repository access
        
2.  Targets
    *   Customer’s GitHub public repositories that contain GitHub workflows
    *   Sensitive data or secrets within used within the workflow including the GITHUB\_TOKEN
    *   Another customer’s GitHub repository (possible if the GITHUB\_TOKEN from one repo has been given access to another repo)
    *   Commit malicious code by exploiting a race condition
        
3.  Attack Vectors
    *   Script injection
    *   Exploit race condition
    *   Through a 3rd-party Action
    *   Emerging threats against software supply chain
threats.threat_action: exploit insecure GitHub Actions settings
threats.threat_impact: execution of unauthorized code in the CI/CD pipeline

threats.comments:
These actions include

*   Change repository visibility
*   Disable branch protection rules
*   Transfer ownership
*   Achieve this repository
*   Delete this repository

1.  Impact:
    *   Change Repository Visibility:
        *   Could expose sensitive proprietary information, proprietary algorithms, internal tools, and/or confidential data. This could trigger severe financial, legal, and reputational consequences for the customer.
        *   Changing from public to private could limit community collaboration.
     *   Disable Branch Protection Rules:
	        *   Could allow unauthorized changes to important branches, compromising data integrity and code quality.
    *   Transfer Ownership:
		*   Could result in the repository being controlled by an unauthorized entity, potentially exposing sensitive proprietary information, proprietary algorithms, internal tools, and/or confidential data. Also reputation damage.
	   *   Archive the Repository:
            *   This would make the repository read-only and could disrupt development and usage.
        *   Delete the Repository:
            
            *   There might be a loss of code, version history, documentation, and other project-related data. However, data can be recovered up to [90 days](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/restoring-a-deleted-repository) so a period of distribution to productivity is more likely in the case of deletion.
                
            *   This can disrupt software development, potentially result in financial losses, and damage an organization’s reputation.
                
2.  Targets
	*   User’s sessions or credentials
	*   Token’s that have access to the customer’s GitHub organizations
	*   Access to another system that would lead to gaining access to GitHub e.g. Vault
        
3.  Attack Vectors
    *   Social engineering, tools to steal sessions, secret scanning tools run against source code repositories, unintentional leaks through video walkthroughs or documentation, leaked dumps of databases and other systems on the black market and generally exposed secrets
    *   An employee unintentionally changing one of these settings
    *   A machine user unintentionally changing one of these settings
threats.threat_action: modify critical repository settings in the Danger Zone
threats.threat_impact: unauthorized repository configuration changes

impacted_assets: system boundary controls and environment separation
threats.prerequisites: with access to shared development environments
threats.threat_action: mix production and development repository configurations
threats.threat_impact: accidental deployment of test code to production systems
